class.name: Word.TableCollection
class.description: Contains the collection of the document's Table objects.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the request context from a TableCollection to verify the connection between the add-in and Word before performing table operations.

properties.name: items
properties.description: Gets the loaded child items in this collection.

examples.description: Get all tables in the document and log the count and row count of each table to the console.

methods.name: getFirst
methods.description: Gets the first table in this collection. Throws an ItemNotFound error if this collection is empty.

examples.description: Retrieve and display the text content from the first cell (row 0, column 0) of the first table in the document.

methods.name: getFirstOrNullObject
methods.description: Gets the first table in this collection. If this collection is empty, then this method will return an object with its isNullObject property set to true. For further information, see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/develop/application-specific-api-model#ornullobject-methods-and-properties.

examples.description: Check if the document contains any tables and display an alert with the first table's row count, or notify the user if no tables exist.

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: propertyNamesAndPaths.select is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and propertyNamesAndPaths.expand is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

examples.description: Load all tables in the document and display the count of tables found

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). (JSON.stringify, in turn, calls the toJSON method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original Word.TableCollection object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.TableCollectionData) that contains an "items" array with shallow copies of any loaded properties from the collection's items.

examples.description: Export all tables in the document to JSON format for logging or external processing

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/office/officeextension.clientrequestcontext#office-officeextension-clientrequestcontext-trackedobjects-member. If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

examples.description: Track all tables in a document and modify their properties across multiple sync calls without losing object references

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/office/officeextension.clientrequestcontext#office-officeextension-clientrequestcontext-trackedobjects-member. Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call context.sync() before the memory release takes effect.

examples.description: Load all tables in the document, process their data, then untrack them to free memory and improve performance.
